reviewText:
Cheese hungry mice in a 'World of Goo' bridge builder clone"
First I was looking forward to play this game. I got it when it was reduced by 98% to 0.21 EUR. After playing the first levels I feel about this is not really a creative new concept of bridge builder game.

Rather it's the same old overtaken principle of 'World of Goo': to build as less as possible triangles to reach a goal. The game proclaims to be very "challenging". But in the end you have the same problem like in 'World of Goo': There's only one perfect solution (OCD) to reach the 3 stars goal.

Why to repeat the old mistakes I wonder. Couldn't it be a funny
date:
not so challenging physics bridge builder game? But apparently the overstimulated kids from today love to sit hours over simple graphics to find the adequate angle solution that their bridges bendover in the right moment. Sigh ! Where is the fun in this?

At least you have a hint option which refills for one hint / 10-15 min. Seems you have to "hint grind" through each level to unlock the "collect every star" achievement.

PS. And the leaderboards are also pointless if you have just ppl doing "hint solutions"."

reviewText:
It's important to note that this review is based off the PC version of the game.

Sometimes an App needs to just stay out of the PC market, and stay as an App. This is the only thing I could think of during my time with Ratventure Challenge. The games genre is a simple one, build a bridge and get object A to point B. There are many of this type of these games in the genre, I haven't really played many of them. Names like Bridge Constructor, World of Goo, etc, jump to mind, just to name a few. The genre has never really garnered much interest in me, it always seemed rather repetitive. With Ratventure Challenge, I thought it would be a nice, interesting, way to break myself into the genre.

For the most part it does the job. The physics of the game can be a little strange and the game has some very odd design decisions, all of which we will be discussing here in this review. So lets start with something obvious. If you noticed at the top of this article, many prices are listed, ranging from five bucks to two bucks. Normally I don't list prices of the game on my blog, because I feel monetary value of a game is different from person to person. However in this case, I wanted to use them as a object point to a particular issue I have with this title. There is NO difference between the three versions of the game. Why is there a price difference? Simply for the pleasure of playing that game on that particular device? Now, I could ramble on about how this all seems shady but I will leave it at that for now.

Straight from when you launch the game, Ratventure screams App. There isn't any retooling of options, buttons, or even the way you can interact with the screen. There are absolutely no graphics control or option menus present whatsoever. All you're left with is a sound off/on, music off/on button.

The game also is stuck in 1280/720 resolution, if you wanted to play it on full screen, there is no in-game way of doing this currently. For a PC port this is rather disappointing in most regards.

Now let's get to the good stuff, the game play. Now if you were to ask me simply, is the game fun? I would say yes, ignoring all the other issues the game has a whole. The game is simple enough to play, with you building small pieces in a massive wooden structure, in hopes of getting some delicious cheese. The puzzles vary in difficulty and sometimes not in order. One level is ridiculously hard and then the next will be rather easy. I think this issue has to do with the fact that Ratventure doesn't really evolve all too much as a game. There are buzz-saws and rope hooks to change things up occasionally, but for the most part your building pieces never evolve or change.

Level designs are varied enough as you progress deeper into the games 72 levels and some of them can be quite the brain tickler. To help you along is a handy hint button that does a fairly good job of showing how to do it in the 3 star requirement. However, it doesn't let you do it step by step more then it shows it all at once and expects you to remember, this is probably done on purpose as it would be too easy otherwise. The game also features a useful Undo last action button" that doesn't really work at all. The button only lets you undo the last action and sometimes not at all depending on what happens in the game. The game is full of these strange little inconveniences. As an example

reviewText:
Ratventure Challenge follows 2 rats on their lifelong ambition to collect cheese. If you are familiar with physics-based bridge builders like World of Goo you should know what to expect. Six distinct worlds await, all containing 12 levels. Difficulty gradually increases either by giving you fewer blocks, asking for larger towers to be constructed or by placing more obstacles in your way.
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=d2w_5j3iErA
It's a shame to have to down vote on the basis of in-game transactions link. Because the simulation itself is quite good, as are the controls. While not required to progress generally both steam users and valve frown upon such things and they really have no place in full priced pc games.  Other downside would be the lack of in-game options, Music had no volume slider so it was either on or off and couldn't run in full screen, was locked to a window @1280x768.

Perhaps a little on the easy side I've not progressed far enough to make final judgement. With the in-game transactions removed and some video options added, I would give it the thumbsup as otherwise the price is about right and game is quite enjoyable. Cheers folks. :)

EDIT:
In-game purchases were completely removed by request. While the game still lacks video options it's not worth completely overlooking if you enjoy playing with physics or puzzle games. Developer has also apologized for the over-reaction and community banning me for no reason, these things happen.  Happy Gaming!

reviewText:
Update: The developer was very responsive, and pushed an update shortly after I delivered a crash log. It appears to have fixed the issue.

As for the game, it's much like World of Goo and similar tower-building games. I kind of liked it, but I got bored easily.

-----

It crashes all the time on OS X 10.10.3 due to programming errors involving the undo stack (update: actually, settings) and null pointers.
Looks like the programming is pretty awful, or the UI library is awful, or the OS X testing is sub-standard.

reviewText:
An OK mobile port with better options available on the PC.

Pros:
Tiny Bridge: Ratventure has some things going for it.  It has an attractive art style and a whimsical premise.  It is currently on sale and very cheap.

Cons:
Sadly, quite a few cons in this one.
- First, it is obviously a mobile port.  There doesn't seem to have been much done in this conversion, including a lack of resolution options.  Sound and music are only toggles.
- There is only one solution to three star a level, the solution that you can get by looking at the hints.  This takes away from any creativity that might have been part of the process.  Each level is simply a puzzle with one right solution.  That would be OK if not for....
- Sometimes there are bugs.  The thin mouse sometimes gets lost and does not move.  Also, for a physics based game the underlying physics engine does not seem up to the task at times.  Sometimes, despite standing on top of your goal (the cheese), your mice seem unintersted in picking it up.  Maybe because you didn't follow the hint button map exactly.


The presentation isn't bad, and if you don't mind a simple puzzle game timewaster with a single solution you can get hints for, this is the game for you.  If you are looking for the next World of Goo, look elsewhere.

4/10

reviewText: It's pretty frustrating to be honest. I enjoy a good puzzle game, but the physics are just too janky and the requirements are too precise. So it could have been a fun little game where you build a few different designs and there are a few options on each level, to get creative with. But each one has been built with a very specific solution on mind and because the wooden structures bounce around a lot with movement, sometimes even the exact same design will fail one time but work the next. So to finish the game with 3 stars becomes a grind or trial and error over and over. Anyhow I did it and I'm sure others will be able to as well, but I'd suggest that any other games in the series either tone down the bounciness of the structures or reduce the precision required to navigate the levels and let people come up with designs of their own to solve the problem.\nI'd say it was a thumbs sideways, but that's not an option, so call it a thumbs down in the hopes that people who want to play this understand that it's not as simple as the art style and gameplay trailer suggest.

reviewText:
NOTE:  I was provided a free copy of this game by the developers for review and video gameplay revealed on my Youtube channel.  Please search my username ZAXTOR99 on Youtube to find my video review as the Steam Youtube links are not currently working.

Even though I was provided with a free evaluation copy of this new strategy puzzle game by the developers, my goal of providing honest feedback to my viewers doesn't change at all...

With that, this game offers a decent amount of fun and strategy challenge in the few levels that I played, and that challenge is obviously growing with every successful level conquered.

The goal is to stretch triangular extensions of woodwork out in under the maximum number of moves allowed on each level to form a web" or bridge for the rats to cross and get the cheese pieces on each level.  You must be careful in how you extend this framework as it is weight and physics based
recommended: hurdles such as spinning saw blades present added danger and challenge to your efforts.\n\nThe problems I find in this game is that it just doesn't add anything to the game that it will likely remind every one

reviewText:
Full Disclosure: Copy supplied by the developer for review.
What happens when you take World of Goo and combine it with Bridge Builder?! Well, you get Tiny Bridge Ratventure. The basic premise of the game is to traverse 2 rats through a hostile terrain by building structures to collect cheese. The main principal of this physics basic bridge builder is nothing new as there are a lot of these type of games on the market but Ratventure does offer a few different mechanics that set it asside from the rest. Regardless of Ratventures small amount originalities, they still do not justify a $10.99 price point. My recommendation is only to buy it on sale (like $.21).

Lets look at the good (pro's), the bad (con's), and the ugly (straight-up no no's").

The Good (Pro's) is that I am partial to these physics based bridge builder type games. The developer Estelion added player semi-controlled mechanics (opposed to automated as most bridge builder games are but movement is limited to points on the structure) making traversing the structure a little more difficult with hazards on the map. To add to the difficulty
date: they've added bonus cheese for extra points in addition to the level ending big cheese. The non-player controlled mechanics (I want to call these sprites "enemies" but they both help and hinder progress
recommended: so we will label them as "NPC's") have both positive and negative affects on your structure
hoursPlayed: sometimes making it bounce and sway
voteText: or adding stability to a structure. Building on to your structure while while its swaying all over the screen adds a challenge as well as a lot more teadium to the time it takes to build. Though you are limited to only building strut parts to your structure
helpfulPercent: in addition to the NPC's there are added variables for your bridge in the maps. These include ancor points and rope suspenders
votesHelpful: both of which you have little to no placement control over.\n\nThe Bad (Con's) is that there are a lot of these games to choose from. Most of which at the same price point (not on sale) offer better graphics
votesFunny: more gameplay options or are just cheaper. Next

reviewText:
A tower/bridge building game where you need to get two rats across dangerous cliffs and saw blades to the precious cheese for consumption.

This game is based on bridge builders and other apps of that similar nature and does it relatively well, the physics are sorta wierd and don't always make sense but it is a game about rats with clothing and briefcases looking for cheese in dangerous worlds.

The art and music are decent, nothing overly special but suit the game just well.

3 different chapters are available and have about 10-15 levels each, taking you about 1 hour per chapter (more so if you find 1 particular episode hard)

Its relaxing and easy gameplay and user friendly, with hints and contruction help along the way. The one thing I have to say that makes me not recommend this game is the insane price for such a small, short and simple game. 12$ is incrediby overprice for a game worst maybe 5$. Complete review killer right there.

Personal Rating: 2/5

reviewText: It never occured to me how lucky we were with World of Goo, how many tiny things there are that the developer needs to get right so that the game would be fun. The creators of Tiny Bridge weren't so skillful / lucky, and as a result, the game is irritating instead of fun. It's difficult to point out what exactly is wrong - the music is killing my nerves, the lack of multistep undo punishes experimentation, and the balancing methods are questionable at the very least, but I feel I'm only scratching the surface with these. However, I stopped after 2-3, and that's probably telling more. The basic idea was sound (if you can forgive so blatantly ripping of WoG, which I can), and it could have been a good game, but in the end, it isn't. Too bad - not refund bad, but bad :(

reviewText:
The physics of this game make no sense, the characters can't even walk on land; they have to walk on your structure.
I couldn't even get past the 2nd level and it took me a long time to figure out what to do in the 1st level. Also, clicking on the hint button removes your structure.

Conclusion: Maybe I just don't know how to play, but anyone that likes games like this; just go play World of Goo instead. World of Goo is much easier to play.

reviewText:
I got this game for next to nothing in a sale, free after selling the cards.. I didn't have high expectations but I was still left feeling really disappointed with it.

The biggest problem I had with it is the physics, given that it's a physics game it's a real issue for the game when the main aspect of the game just fails.
It feels a bit too bouncy"
date: like the wood is made out of rubber
recommended: no matter how much support you add
hoursPlayed: all your structure/bridge wants to do is wobble
voteText: flail around and isn't able to stay firmly in  one place.\nYou can copy a hint
helpfulPercent: 100% to how it's shown and still not be able to do the level..In most cases the hint shown is the only solution to solve the level. Little creativity can be done; making it really dull.\n\nI think the biggest frustration I had with the game and made me abandon it was that if you did a test run and then ended it the contraption doesn't 'pause'
votesHelpful: it still keeps the same momentum it had before leaving it to break even in construction mode.\nAs it's still able to move during this phase it leaves it being a pain in the ♥♥♥ to build
votesTotal: you can fail before you even start testing it. It's irritating and a buggy mess.\n\nThere's so many bridge construction games out there which are much better off than this
votesFunny: it had a nice idea but the game is just poorly made.\n\nNot worth buying it but you can get it for nothing when it gets a high discount
commentsCount: the bundle it's included in has some nice games though but don't expect any enjoyment from Tiny Bridge: Ratventure."

reviewText:
I have recieved this game for free as part of a promotion for the game. Regardless of whether I paid for it or not, I remain unbiased in all of my reviews. My reviews reflect my opinion, and my opinion only.

Is it bad I actually enjoy this one? Okay, so, I loved World of Goo. It was cute, it was fun, it was perfect. This one works off of a similar mechanic, the only difference being now you have two rats you have to get across that put weight on your structures. Makes for some interesting gameplay, I look forward to playing more. The style, the premise and the music are all simple and fun.

Would I spend $20 on it? Not necessarily, but I would pay $10... That's saying a lot coming from me since I rarely buy a game over $5 these days.

reviewText:
Ratventure Challenge – A Steam Review
[Disclamer - I was provided a copy by the publisher for review purposes]

12.05.2015 UPDATE - Today's update removed microtransactions and added a restart button, so two of my earlier negative points raised are now futile.


In-game microtransactions. That's a big no-no for a PC game.
Convoluted menu that makes restarting the level a chore. Multiple times I've pressed undo while trying to reset the level

It's a very good thing when the developer listens to the community and acts accordingly. Thumbs up


The good

Easy to learn, hard to master gameplay
Clean graphics and enjoyable soundThe not so good:

Sometimes the tall skinny rat didn't want to move, thus having to restart the level.
The conclusion:

Bridge builder with nice clean graphics. It's a good puzzler and will keep you entertained for a while.

You can see me playing it here - http://youtu.be/aQmHx-cdtVc
voteText: 14 of 36 people (39%) found this review helpful 2 people found this review funny

reviewText:
Game: Ratventure Challenge
Genre: Dynamic Bridge Builder
Developer: Estelion
Publisher: Estelion
Copy supplied by developer

Ratventure Challenge is the port of an iOS puzzle game (or dynamic bridge builder" as the creators like to call it) developed and published by Estelion. It's about a couple of rats who want an unlimited amount of cheese
date: and that's what they do for the entire game.\n\nGRAPHICSThe characters and background don't look bad or anything
recommended: but the repetitive levels and poor animations show the game's nature as mobile game port.\n\nGAMEPLAYYour goal is to reach the big piece of cheese at the other end of the level
hoursPlayed: while trying to use less pieces of wood for your bridge as possible
voteText: as well as collecting as many pieces of cheese as possible to get an higher score at the end of level. Either I am really bad at this game
helpfulPercent: or there is something wrong with the physics. Most of the time
votesHelpful: you will feel really frustrated by the unintuitive gameplay. There is a hint system which tells you exactly what to do to beat a level
votesTotal: but having to alternate between constructing and moving the rats doesn't make things easier and show that not much love was put into the port.\n\nCHALLENGEThe game doesn't feel challenging
votesFunny: but frustrating. The physics are illogical
commentsCount:
the level design is not all that great and there is no learning curve: you'll find yourself going from an easy level to an hard one to an easy one again in a matter of seconds.

SOUNDRepetitive music? Check. Poor amount of sound effects? Double check. Music not playing randomly? TRIPLE CHECK.

REPLAYABILITYOther than trying to get an high-score in each of the 72 levels
column16: there aren't secrets or unlockables that will make you come back to this game.\n\nThis game is not for me
column17: mostly because of its obvious nature as an iOS port and the terrible physics. The game is relatively cheap
column18: and if you like this genre then you will love this and have a good time. Otherwise
column19:
you would be wasting money.

Story: n/a
Graphics: 6
Gameplay: 4.5
Challenge: 5.5
Sound: 3.5
Replayability: 5

ENJOYMENT: 4.5
FRUSTRATION: 8
Follow me on Twitter: @nickygra97
Subscribe to my channel
Like on Facebook

reviewText: When I saw the screenshots of this game I thought hmm I am getting this cause this is reminding me of World of Goo and I loved that game. I was wrong. This game is no way fun like World of Goo, this game is more like frustrating. First when I launched the game I saw it's in windowed mode so I tried going fullscreen with Alt + Enter because I didn't find any settings about this game and that didn't work I spend a few minutes trying to figure it out until I decided to check the Community Hub for this game and come to find out this game doesn't have Full screen mode at all which is frustrating. Then I jump into the game and the mechanics are broken sometimes, like one of the mice will fail to move, sometimes the mice will ignore the cheese completely and sometimes the bridges won't place like you want them. You will end up getting one stars and two stars and not realising what you have to do or why you did get or did not get three stars. Also another thing is that the undo function is broken. Maybe I was hyped too much and it effected my opinion on the game for expecting a game like World of Goo or maybe that's not the case at all and that the game is not good but simply I don't like this game and all it did is get me frustrated at it so I cannot recommend it.

reviewText: When I bought it on a sale (about 0,40E) I thought Maybe a nice small bridge building game". But after playing it i realise that it is only a very poor port of a mobile game

reviewText: Tiny Bridge: Ratventure is basically a bridge building game with an active element where you need to move the two rats and gather the cheese pieces as the structure you built swing and stretch based on the weight. It is a puzzle game that has been done before, but usually, the units (lemmings, monkeys, etc.) move on their own logic toward the exit, rather than you controlling it. The idea is to use minimum number of moves and minimum number of segments to build the structure. This is obviously a mobile game port, as the structure is identical to many similar action-puzzle games, including the long-lived Angry Birds franchise, where you have multiple stages"
date: each stage containing a dozen or more levels and you can get up to 3 stars per level. The more stars
recommended: the more levels are unlocked. There's not much else to the game though. The trick is in how complicated structure you have to build and how to minimize the steps you have to take to grab all the cheese. As the cheese are further apart and terrain gets trickier
hoursPlayed: the structures you build start to take on Rube Goldberg machine properties even though they aren't supposed to move... much.\n\nIf you want a bridge-building game
voteText: there are better ones. This is a puzzle game similar to Worlds of Goo where you build structures to reach stuff. It's really nothing special."

reviewText: If world of goo is using dynamic stuctures to find static solutions, TBR is using static structures to find dynamic solutions. All but the earliest levels will rely on your bridge bending, breaking, or falling off a cliff to solve the puzzle. It's a neat idea, but between the interface, the sound design and the infuriating piece placement I can't bring myself to reccomend it. It all becomes a chore far too quickly.\n\nSteam really needs a meh" review option
date: but in lieu of than it's getting a thumbs down."

reviewText:
When I originally bought this, I was looking forward to playing this. It was alright for the first 5 - 10 levels, but then it became dull and boring for me. However, this is just my personal preference.


Pros:
- Game is rather simple.
- The physics are okay.

Cons:
- Redundant gameplay. Feels like you are playing the same levels over and over.
- Building" the bridge is VERY limited to what you can do.
- Game play overall feels a lot like Angry Birds; try and get 3 stars on every level to unlock more levels.
- The background music doesn't really help the "fun" factor. It's cute
date:
but hearing the same thing loop over and over gets old fast.


Again
recommended: everyone has their own opinion. This is just mine."

I think it worths $1.99 but not $10.99."
